title: WARP discussion about what way to take

i.c: WARP discussion about what way to take

title: I want to create a laravel project where i would like to implement ddd-hexagonal... there are publishers and subscribers... i could use User for authentication and some other models related to user... For instance, a User publisher could have be related to a Publisher and to several subscribers if the subscription is private... (Subscribers are invited by Publisher)... There could also be Publishers with public content for any subscriber... Last you can have a User subscriber related to an instance of Subscriber... Other models : Notification (belongs to publisher), Subscription (belongs to subscribers)... So far i have only work in Laravel, there is no Hexagonal squeleton... Models, Migrations, Factories, Seeders... Roadmap?.

i.c: want to create a laravel project where i would like to implement ddd-hexagonal... there are publishers and subscribers... i could use User for authentication and some other models related to user... For instance, a User publisher could have be related to a Publisher and to several subscriber

if the subscription is private... (Subscribers are invited by Publisher)... There could also be Publishers with public content for any subscriber... Last you can have a User subscriber related to an instance of Subscriber... Other models : Notification (belongs to publisher), Subscription (belongs to subscribers)... So far i have only work in Laravel, there is no Hexagonal squeleton... Models, Migrations, Factories, Seeders... Roadmap?

title: Rapid Development: Laravel provides excellent tooling (Artisan, Eloquent, etc.)

i.c: Rapid Development: Laravel provides excellent tooling (Artisan, Eloquent, etc.)

title: Ecosystem: Rich package ecosystem for common needs

i.c: Ecosystem: Rich package ecosystem for common needs

title: Team Familiarity: Your team knows Laravel

i.c: Team Familiarity: Your team knows Laravel

title: Infrastructure: Database migrations, queues, caching, etc.

i.c: Infrastructure: Database migrations, queues, caching, etc.

title: Deployment: Laravel deployment patterns are well-established

i.c: Deployment: Laravel deployment patterns are well-established

title: But you're right to question it!
h
red

i.c: But you're right to question it!

title: Use Laravel as Infrastructure only - Domain/Application layers have zero Laravel dependencies

i.c: Use Laravel as Infrastructure only - Domain/Application layers have zero Laravel dependencies

title: Use a lighter framework like Slim, or even pure PHP

i.c: Use a lighter framework like Slim, or even pure PHP

title: Use a different language entirely - Python, Go, Node.js, etc.

i.c: Use a different language entirely - Python, Go, Node.js, etc.

title: Use microservices - Each bounded context as separate service

i.c: Use microservices - Each bounded context as separate service

title: A) Hexagonal within Laravel (Laravel provides infrastructure conveniences)
h
yellow

•  Domain/Application pure, but Laravel handles web, DB, queues, etc.
•  Easier migration from your existing Laravel project

i.c: A) Hexagonal within Laravel (Laravel provides infrastructure conveniences)

•  Domain/Application pure, but Laravel handles web, DB, queues, etc.
•  Easier migration from your existing Laravel project

title: B) Pure Hexagonal (Laravel is just one replaceable adapter)
h
yellow

i.c: B) Pure Hexagonal (Laravel is just one replaceable adapter)

title:
•  Complete framework independence
•  Maximum flexibility but more boilerplate
•  Could replace Laravel with anything

i.c:
•  Complete framework independence
•  Maximum flexibility but more boilerplate
•  Could replace Laravel with anything

title: C) Different approach entirely : Microservices
h
yellow

•  Microservices with each bounded context separate
•  Event-driven architecture
•  CQRS + Event Sourcing

i.c:
•  Microservices with each bounded context separate
•  Event-driven architecture
•  CQRS + Event Sourcing

title: Since you already have Laravel models/migrations,
Option A
h
yellow
might be most practical - use Laravel's infrastructure capabilities while keeping your core business logic completely independent. But if you want true architectural purity,
Option B
h
yellow
is the way to go.

i.c: Since you already have Laravel models/migrations,
might be most practical - use Laravel's infrastructure capabilities while keeping your core business logic completely independent. But if you want true architectural purity,

title:
What's your preference? Are you looking to:
•  Leverage Laravel's ecosystem while achieving clean architecture?
•  Or achieve maximum architectural purity regardless of framework convenience?

i.c:
What's your preference? Are you looking to:
•  Leverage Laravel's ecosystem while achieving clean architecture?
•  Or achieve maximum architectural purity regardless of framework convenience?

title: This will fundamentally change how we approach the design!

i.c: This will fundamentally change how we approach the design!

title:
laravel-project/
├── app/
│   ├── Models/ (existing Laravel models - infrastructure adapters)
│   ├── Http/
│   │   └── Controllers/ (thin Laravel controllers)
│   ├── Domain/ (pure business logic - zero Laravel dependencies)
│   │   ├── Publisher/
│   │   │   ├── Entities/
│   │   │   │   ├── Publisher.php
│   │   │   │   └── Notification.php
│   │   │   ├── Repositories/
│   │   │   │   └── PublisherRepositoryInterface.php
│   │   │   ├── ValueObjects/
│   │   │   └── Services/
│   │   │       └── NotificationDomainService.php
│   │   ├── Subscriber/
│   │   │   ├── Entities/
│   │   │   ├── Repositories/
│   │   │   ├── ValueObjects/
│   │   │   └── Services/
│   │   └── Shared/
│   │       ├── ValueObjects/
│   │       └── Events/
│   ├── Application/ (use cases - framework agnostic)
│   │   ├── UseCases/
│   │   │   ├── Publisher/
│   │   │   ├── Subscriber/
│   │   │   └── Notification/
│   │   ├── DTOs/
│   │   └── Ports/ (interfaces)
│   └── Infrastructure/ (Laravel-specific implementations)
│       ├── Repositories/
│       │   ├── EloquentPublisherRepository.php
│       │   └── EloquentSubscriberRepository.php
│       ├── Http/
│       │   └── Adapters/
│       └── Providers/
├── database/ (Laravel conveniences)
│   ├── migrations/
│   ├── factories/
│   └── seeders/
└── routes/
    └── api.php

: Slim (yes!), or multiple lightweight frameworks
Philosophy

: Each bounded context as separate service

title: Option B
h
yellow
: No framework (pure PHP with Composer) or multiple interchangeable frameworks

i.c: No framework (pure PHP with Composer) or multiple interchangeable frameworks

title: Option C
h
yellow
: Slim for each service (lightweight, perfect for microservices) + potentially other frameworks per service

i.c: : Slim for each service (lightweight, perfect for microservices) + potentially other frameworks per service

title: Option A
h
yellow
: Keep Laravel - you get migrations, queues, caching, Artisan commands
Option B
h
yellow
: Start with pure PHP/Composer, add frameworks as adapters later
Option C
h
yellow
: Slim for PHP services, could mix with Node.js/Go/Python per service needs

i.c: : Keep Laravel - you get migrations, queues, caching, Artisan commands
: Start with pure PHP/Composer, add frameworks as adapters later
: Slim for PHP services, could mix with Node.js/Go/Python per service needs

title: Which option resonates with your vision? Each has very different implications for development, testing, deployment, and team workflow.

i.c: Which option resonates with your vision? Each has very different implications for development, testing, deployment, and team workflow.

title: This is the heart of your application, containing pure business logic with no external dependencies.

i.c: This is the heart of your application, containing pure business logic with no external dependencies.

title: Orchestrates business logic and coordinates between domain and infrastructure.

i.c: Orchestrates business logic and coordinates between domain and infrastructure.

title: Handles persistence, external APIs, and Laravel-specific implementations.

i.c: Handles persistence, external APIs, and Laravel-specific implementations.

title: Repositories (Interfaces in Domain, Implementations in Infrastructure)
h
yellow

i.c: Repositories (Interfaces in Domain, Implementations in Infrastructure)
